Further details on how WAfriM is defined and used throughout the Report are provided in Annex V.Global surface temperature See Global mean surface temperature (GMST)  and Global mean surface air temperature (GSAT) . See also Global warming .Global warming Global warming refers to the increase in global surface temperature  relative to a baseline reference period , averaging over a period sufficient to remove interannual variations (e.g., 20 or 30 years). IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2021, p.1825: been the 100,000-year glacial–interglacial cycles when climate was mostly cooler than at present. Global surface temperatures have typically varied by 5°C to 7°C through these cycles, with large changes in ice volume and sea level, and temperature changes as great as 10°C to 15°C in some middle and high latitude regions of the Northern Hemisphere. Since the end of the last ice age, about 10,000 years ago, global surface temperatures have probably fluctuated by little more than 1°C. Some fluctuations have lasted several centuries, including the period 1400–1900 which ended in the 19th century and which appears to have been global in extent. The limited available evidence from proxy climate indicators suggests that the 20th century global mean temperature is at least as warm as any other century since at least 1400 AD. Data prior to 1400 are too sparse to allow the reliable estimation of global mean temperature. New analyses of proxy data

The figure depicts frequencies and increases in intensity of 10- or 50-year extreme events from the base period (1850–1900) under different global warming levels.Hot temperature extremes are defined as the daily maximum temperatures over land that were exceeded on average once in a decade (10-year event) or once in 50 years (50-year event) during the 1850–1900 reference period. Do not include any knowledge from outside of these sources. Only write a single paragraph. Each sentence must end with the reference in the form of (author, year, page number). Stricly follow this format. Citing multiple sources in one sentence is not allowed.                    However, if no source addresses the question, admit truthfully that no answer can be given.                    Answer the question concisly and avoid being verbose.
gpt-35: The global mean temperature refers to the average surface temperature of the Earth relative to a baseline reference period. It is typically measured over a period of 20 or 30 years to remove interannual variations. The most common baseline is the period from 1850 to 1900, although more modern baselines can be used depending on the application (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2020, p.16203). Over the past 10,000 years, global surface temperatures have fluctuated by little more than 1°C, with some fluctuations lasting several centuries (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2021, p.1825). However, in the last 50 years, global temperatures have increased at a rate unprecedented in at least the last 2000 years (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2018, p.2026). The sources do not provide a specific numerical value for the current global mean temperature.
gpt-4: The global mean temperature refers to the average temperature of the Earth's surface, measured relative to a baseline reference period and averaged over a period sufficient to remove interannual variations, such as 20 or 30 years (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2020, p.16203). A common choice for the baseline is 1850–1900, which is the earliest period of reliable observations with sufficient geographic coverage (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2020, p.16203).

TemperatureBetween 1880 and 2012, global average temperatures increased by 0 .85oC [0 .65°C – 1 .06oC], with the last three decades successively warmer than any preceding decade since 1850 (IPCC, 2014a) . Even under conservative scenarios temperatures are projected to rise further, with temperatures at the end of the 21st century likely to be 1 .5oC or more higher relative to 1850-1900 under most scenarios (IPCC, 2014a) . Many temperate and subtropical species, as well as some tropical species, have shifted their geographic ranges, and altered their phenology and migration patterns in recent years in response to ongoing climatic changes, particularly temperature (Walther et al., 2002; Parmesan & Yohe, 2003; Menzel et al., 2006; Parmesan, 2006; Lenoir et al., 2008; Chen et al., 2009; Pauli et al., 2012; Telwala et al., 2013; IPCC 2014a, 2014b) (also see Chapter 4, Section 4 .2 .8) .

IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2019, p.1863: Observed changes in the atmosphere, oceans, cryosphere and biosphere provide unequivocal evidence of a world that has warmed. Over the past several decades, key indicators of the climate system are increasingly at levels unseen in centuries to millennia, and are changing at rates unprecedented in at least the last 2000 years ( high confidence ). Temperatures as high as during the most recent decade (2011–2020) exceed the warmest centennial-scale range reconstructed for the present interglacial, around 6,500 years ago [0.2°C–1°C relative to 1850–1900] ( medium confidence ). The next older warm period is the last interglacial when the multi-centennial temperature range about 125,000 years ago [0.5°C–1.5°C relative to 1850–1900] encompassed the recent decade values ( medium confidence ). {2.3}GMST increased by 0.85 [0.69 to 0.95] °C between 1850–1900 and 1995–2014 and by 1.09 [0.95 to 1.20] °C between 1850–1900 and 2011–2020. gpt-35: The world's temperature has increased by 0.85°C between 1850-1900 and 1995-2014, and by 1.09°C between 1850-1900 and 2011-2020 (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2019, p.1863). It is projected that temperatures will continue to rise, with temperatures at the end of the 21st century likely to be 1.5°C or more higher relative to 1850-1900 under most scenarios (ipbes_assessment_report_ldra_EN, 2022, p.1283).
gpt-4: Between 1880 and 2012, global average temperatures increased by 0.85°C, with the last three decades successively warmer than any preceding decade since 1850 (ipbes_assessment_report_ldra_EN, 2022, p.1283). The temperature increase in 2011–2020 was 1.09°C (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2021, p.401). Even under conservative scenarios, temperatures are projected to rise further, with temperatures at the end of the 21st century likely to be 1.5°C or more higher relative to 1850-1900 under most scenarios (ipbes_assessment_report_ldra_EN, 2022, p.1283).

Natural variations in global temperatures are considered to be low, as compared to such human-induced warming. The latter is growing beyond a threshold that could not have been otherwise exceeded through natural variation (Herring et al. , 2016; IPCC,  2014).Human-induced warming reached ~1 °C (±0.2°C) above pre-industrial levels in 2017, with rises of 0.2°C (±0.1°C) per decade (IPCC, 2018) . Impacts include thermal stress, coral bleaching, and melting of sea and land ice (IPCC, 2013). The highest velocities in temperature change are found in flat landscapes and at higher latitudes (Loarie et al., 2009). Most land regions are warming faster than the average, most ocean regions slower (UNFCCC, 2015). Evidence of long-term geophysical and biological changes

Widespread and rapid changes in the atmosphere, ocean, cryosphere and biosphere have occurred.   {2.2, 2.3, Cross-Chapter Box 2.3, 3.3, 3.4, 3.5, 3.6, 3.8, 5.2, 5.3, 6.4, 7.3, 8.3, 9.2, 9.3, 9.5, 9.6, Cross-Chapter Box 9.1} (Figure SPM.1, Figure SPM.2)A.1.1  Observed increases in well-mixed greenhouse gas (GHG) concentrations since around 1750 are unequivocally caused by human activities. Higher CO2 concentrations may increase photosynthetic rates directly (CO2 fertilization) and also water-use efficiency, thereby reducing drought susceptibility (Li et al., 2017; Long et al., 2004) . However, increased plant growth can eventually be reduced by nitrogen limitation (Beier et al.,  2008) and ultimately the vegetation may succumb to direct negative effects of changes in mean and extreme climate (Lobell et al., 2011; Lobell & Gourdji, 2012) . Climate change results in changes in soil processes which can also lead to changes in productivity (Beier et al., 2008; Várallyay, 2010) .  In cold and wet areas, warming increases the decomposition rate of soil organic matter and availability of soil nutrients (Goldblum & Rigg, 2010; Zhao & Running, 2010) .

However, the overall change in land carbon also depends on land-use change and on the response of vegetation and soil to continued warming and changes in the water cycle, including increased droughts in some regions that will diminish the sink capacity. In addition, the net flux of atmospheric and continental freshwater is a key driver of sea surface salinity, which in turn influences the density and circulation of the ocean (Chapter 9). Understanding the interactions between the water and energy cycles is one of the four core projects of the World Climate Research Programme (WCRP). Latent heat fluxes, released by condensation of atmospheric water vapour and absorbed by evaporative processes, are critical to driving the circulation of the atmosphere on scales ranging from individual thunderstorm cells to the global circulation of the atmosphere (Stocker et al., 2013; Miralles et al., 2019). As in any system, many feedback decompositions are possible, each of them highlighting a particular property or aspect of the system (Ingram, 2010; Held and Shell, 2012; Dufresne and Saint-Lu, 2016). The first decomposition considers separately the changes (and therefore feedbacks) in the lapse rate (LR) and specific humidity (WV). The second decomposition considers changes in the lapse rate assuming constant relative humidity (LR*) separately from changes in relative humidity (RH).The specific humidity (WV) feedback, also known as the water-vapour feedback, quantifies the change in radiative flux at the TOA due to changes in atmospheric water vapour concentration associated with a change in global mean surface air temperature. gpt-35: Scientists have a good understanding of the role of water vapor in the Earth's atmosphere. Water vapor is the most important gaseous absorber in the atmosphere and plays a key role in the Earth's radiative budget (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2018, p.7544). It influences climate change and has a considerable impact on both solar and longwave radiative fluxes (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2018, p.7544). Water vapor also regulates the strength of the water-vapor feedback, particularly in the upper troposphere (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2022, p.3039). Understanding the interactions between the water and energy cycles is a core project of the World Climate Research Programme (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2020, p.7543). Overall, scientists have made significant advances in understanding the processes and feedbacks associated with water vapor in the atmosphere (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2022, p.3039).
gpt-4: Scientists have a comprehensive understanding of the role of water vapor in the Earth's climate system. Water vapor is the most important gaseous absorber in the Earth’s atmosphere and plays a key role in the Earth’s radiative budget (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2018, p.7544). It is also the most important natural greenhouse gas and its amount is expected to increase in a global warming context leading to further warming (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2022, p.3039). Furthermore, water vapor is critical to driving the circulation of the atmosphere on scales ranging from individual thunderstorm cells to the global circulation of the atmosphere (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2020, p.7543). Lastly, changes in atmospheric water vapor concentration associated with a change in global mean surface air temperature are quantified through the water-vapour feedback (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2019, p.6799).

Can you respond to the question "What is the "Climate sensitivity"?" by only relying on the sources. Ignore all sources that do not provide an answer to the question.                    Do not include any knowledge from outside of these sources. Only write a single paragraph. Each sentence must end with the reference in the form of (author, year, page number). Stricly follow this format. Citing multiple sources in one sentence is not allowed.                    However, if no source addresses the question, admit truthfully that no answer can be given.                    Answer the question concisly and avoid being verbose.
gpt-35: Climate sensitivity refers to the measure of how much the Earth's climate system responds to changes in radiative forcing, particularly due to greenhouse gas emissions. It is not a one-dimensional mathematical measure, but rather a concept that encompasses various aspects of climate attribution, impact attribution, and the identification of weather sensitivity (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2020, p.18600). Climate sensitivity can be assessed through different approaches, such as analyzing the seasonal cycle in surface temperature (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2020, p.7342) or tracing it to atmospheric convective mixing (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2019, p.7435). It is also influenced by factors like ocean heat transport (Koenigk and Brodeau, 2014, p.3101) and changes in relative humidity (Sherwood et al., 2010b, p.D09104). However, it is important to note that estimates of climate sensitivity can be confounded by internal variability and disequilibrium (Marvel et al., 2018, p.1595) and external influences on cloud trends (Marvel et al., 2015, p.4820). Overall, climate sensitivity is a complex and multifaceted concept that requires a comprehensive understanding of the Earth's climate system and its response to external forcings.

instruction:
Given are the following sources: [BEGIN OF SOURCES]
ipbes_assessment_report_ldra_EN, 2019, p.1283: influence potential future climate .3.4.1.  TemperatureBetween 1880 and 2012, global average temperatures increased by 0 .85oC [0 .65°C – 1 .06oC], with the last three decades successively warmer than any preceding decade since 1850 (IPCC, 2014a) . Even under conservative scenarios temperatures are projected to rise further, with temperatures at the end of the 21st century likely to be 1 .5oC or more higher relative to 1850-1900 under most scenarios (IPCC, 2014a) . Many temperate and subtropical species, as well as some tropical species, have shifted their geographic ranges, and altered their phenology and migration patterns in recent years in response to ongoing climatic changes, particularly temperature (Walther et al., 2002; Parmesan & Yohe, 2003; Menzel et al., 2006; Parmesan, 2006; Lenoir et al., 2008; Chen et al., 2009; Pauli et al., 2012; Telwala et al., 2013; IPCC 2014a, 2014b) (also see Chapter 4, Section 4 .2 .8) .

The traffic light colour system is used as a basis for doing the risks, making it universally understandable. These diagrams are known colloquially as ‘burning ember’ diagrams, and have been a cornerstone of IPCC assessments since the Third Assessment Report, and further developed and updated in subsequent reports. The fact that the diagrams are designed to be simple, intuitive and easily understood with the caption alone has contributed to their longstanding effectiveness. Here, in Figure FAQ16.5.1 below, we provide a simplified figure of this chapter’s burning embers for five categories of global aggregate risk, called Reasons for Concern (RFCs), which collectively synthesise how global risk changes with temperature. The diagram shows the levels of concern that scientists have about the consequences of climate change (for a specified risk category and scope), and how this relates to the level of temperature rise.

Nineteenth-century investigators also established the existence of a natural biogeochemical carbon cycle. Carbon dioxide emitted by volcanoes is removed from the atmosphere through a combination of silicate rock weathering, deep-sea sedimentation, oceanic absorption, and biological storage in plants, shellfish, and other organisms. On multi-million-year time scales, the compression of fossil organic matter is stored as carbon as coal, oil and natural gas (Chamberlin, 1897, 1898; Ekholm, 1901).Arrhenius (1896) calculated that a  doubling of atmospheric CO 2 would produce warming of 5°C–6°C, but in 1900 new measurements seemed to rule out CO 2 as a  greenhouse gas due to overlap with the absorption bands of water vapour (Ångström, 1900; Very and Abbe, 1901). IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2019, p.1065: as a  weather model and more frequently improved. However, all climate models exhibit biases of different degrees and types, and the practice of ‘tuning’ parameter values in models to make their outputs match variables such as historical warming trajectories has generated concern throughout their history (Section 1.5.3.2; Randall and Wielicki, 1997; Edwards, 2010; Hourdin et al., 2017). Overall, AR5 WGI assessed that climate models had improved since previous reports (IPCC, 2013b).Since climate models vary along many dimensions, such as grid type, resolution, and parameterizations, comparing their results requires special techniques. To address this problem, the climate 182Chapter 1 Framing, Context, and Methods1modelling community developed increasingly sophisticated model intercomparison projects (MIPs; Gates et al., 1999; Covey et al., 2003). MIPs prescribe standardized experiment designs, time periods,
IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2021, p.7217: But, unlike in previous assessments, climate models are not considered a line of evidence in their own right in the IPCC Sixth Assessment Report.The ECS of the latest climate models is, on average, higher than that of the previous generation of models and also higher than this Report’s best estimate of 3.0°C. Furthermore, the ECS values in some of the new models are both above and below the 2°C to 5°C very likely  range, and although such models cannot be ruled out as implausible solely based on their ECS, some simulations display climate change that is inconsistent with the observed changes when tested with ancient climates. gpt-35: Climate models have exhibited biases and concerns have been raised about the practice of tuning parameter values to match historical warming trajectories (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2019, p.1065). However, the IPCC Sixth Assessment Report acknowledges that the latest generation of climate models has an average equilibrium climate sensitivity (ECS) higher than previous models and higher than the report's best estimate (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2021, p.7217). Some simulations display climate change inconsistent with observed changes when tested with ancient climates, but a slight mismatch between models and the report's assessment is expected due to improved understanding of the climate system (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2021, p.7217). Therefore, while climate models have had biases and limitations, it is not accurate to say that they have always been wrong.
gpt-4: Climate models have not always been wrong, but they do exhibit biases of different degrees and types, and there has been concern about the practice of 'tuning' parameter values in models to make their outputs match variables such as historical warming trajectories (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2019, p.1065). The latest climate models have an average Equilibrium Climate Sensitivity (ECS) that is higher than that of the previous generation of models and also higher than the best estimate of this report, and some simulations display climate change that is inconsistent with observed changes when tested with ancient climates (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2021, p.7217). However, it is also noted that a slight mismatch between models and this report's assessment is natural because the report's assessment is largely based on observations and an improved understanding of the climate system (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2021, p.7217).

This approach is used in the Atlas chapter and Chapter 12.When assessing changes over the recent past, many studies analyse datasets using a  range of climatologically significant periods (i.e., 30 years or more) with precise start and end dates depending on data availability and the year of the study. Still, it took fifteen years to sign UNCCD into force .Likewise, the time for ecosystem recovery after restoration can vary greatly and should be systematically considered . Many ecosystems can recover assisted or in some cases, non-assisted, from disturbances but the time scale of such processes can span from decades to centuries (Jones & Schmitz, 2009; Kotiaho & Mönkkönen, 2017; Haapalehto, et al., 2017) . For instance, abandoned agricultural lands in Europe could take between several decades to over a century for ecological successions to occur and to naturally become forested (Verburg & Overmars, 2009) . Each sentence must end with the reference in the form of (author, year, page number). Stricly follow this format. Citing multiple sources in one sentence is not allowed. gpt-35: Humanity should worry about the global temperature increase because it leads to successive crop failures and reduced productivity, affecting children's growth and health in developing countries (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2020, p.9387). The expected temperature increase by the end of the century will have devastating health consequences for children, including the incidence of malaria and dengue, and malnutrition, especially in Asian and African countries (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2020, p.9387; Ghosh et al., 2018). Additionally, floods increase the occurrence of diseases and undernutrition in children living in informal settlements and slums in Asia and Africa (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2020, p.9387; Clark et al., 2020). Therefore, the impacts of global temperature increase on children's health and well-being, as well as on food security, highlight the need for concern and action (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2020, p.9387; Ghosh et al., 2018; Clark et al., 2020).
gpt-4: Humanity should worry about the global temperature increase due to a multitude of reasons. Rising temperatures, droughts, and excessive rain can lead to successive crop failures and reduced productivity, which in turn affect children’s growth and health in developing countries (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2020, p.9387). The expected global temperature increase by the end of the century will have devastating health consequences for children, associated with sea level rise, heatwaves, increased incidence of diseases like malaria and dengue, and malnutrition, especially in Asian and African countries (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2020, p.9387). The incidence of floods also increases the occurrence of diseases and undernutrition in children living in informal settlements and slums (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2020, p.9387). The Paris Agreement sets a long-term goal to hold the increase in global average temperature to ‘well below 2°C above pre-industrial levels, and to pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels, recognizing that this would significantly reduce the risks and impacts of climate change (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2018, p.890). Lastly, exposure to multiple and compound climate-related risks increases between 1.5°C and 2°C of global warming, with greater proportions of people both so exposed and susceptible to poverty in Africa and Asia (SPM_version_report_LR, 2020, p.34).

An important question is whether these changes can eventually be reversed, once levels of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere are stabilized or reduced by humans and natural processes. Records from the past can help us answer this question.For at least the last 800,000 years, the Earth has followed cycles of gradual cooling followed by rapid warming caused by natural processes. During cooling phases, more and more ocean water is gradually deposited as snowfall, causing ice sheets to grow and sea level to slowly decrease. During warming phases, the ice sheets melt more quickly, resulting in more rapid rises in sea level (FAQ 9.1, Figure 1). Ice sheets build up very slowly because growth relies on the steady accumulation of falling snow that eventually compacts into ice. IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2021, p.18625: declined over time in most countries owing to general improvements in health care systems, increasing prevalence of residential air conditioning, and behavioural changes. These factors, which determine the susceptibility of the population to heat, have predominated over the influence of temperature change (see ‘Other societal impacts—Heat-related mortality’, Table  SM16.22, De’Donato et  al., 2015; Arbuthnott et al., 2016; Vicedo-Cabrera et al., 2018a). Important exceptions exist, for example, where unprecedented heatwaves have occurred recently. No conclusive evidence emerges regarding recent temporal trends in excess mortality attributable to cold exposure (Vicedo-Cabrera et  al., 2018b). Quantitative detection and attribution studies of temperature-related mortality are still rare. IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2022, p.15232: et al., 2015; Sarofim et al., 2016b; Smith and Sheridan, 2019). Warmer US cities generally experience more mortality from extreme cold events and cold temperatures than colder cities in the USA and Canada (Lee et al., 2014; Gasparrini et al., 2015; Schwartz et al., 2015; Wang et al., 2016; Smith and Sheridan, 2019). While mortality rates linked to direct cold exposure (e.g., hypothermia, falls and fractures) is generally low, the relatively higher mortality during milder temperatures is thought to be largely due to respiratory infections and cardiovascular impacts (Lee et al., 2014; Gasparrini et al., 2015), which, although correlated with temperature, may not be caused by cold temperatures (Ebi and Mills, 2013; Ebi, 2015; Sarofim et al., 2016a). When separating the effects of cold temperatures from the effects of the winter season, one study found that cold temperature did not drive mortality and suggested that

In the worst cases, these lead to organ failure and death (Mora et  al., 2017a; Mora et  al., 2017b). Excess deaths during extreme heat events occur predominantly in older individuals and are overwhelmingly cardiovascular in origin (very high confidence). A higher occurrence of CVD mortality in association with prolonged period of low temperatures has been well documented globally (Giorgini et al., 2017; Stewart et al., 2017); however, there is growing evidence that cardiovascular deaths are more related to heat events than cold spells (Chen et al., 2019; Liu et al., 2015a; Bunker et al., 2016). gpt-35: There is evidence suggesting that more people die from excessive heat than from cold. Studies have shown that improvements in healthcare systems, increased prevalence of residential air conditioning, and behavioral changes have contributed to a decline in heat-related mortality in most countries (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2021, p.18625). Additionally, it has been found that warmer cities generally experience higher mortality rates from extreme cold events and cold temperatures, which are largely attributed to respiratory infections and cardiovascular impacts (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2022, p.15232). While there is a higher occurrence of cardiovascular deaths associated with prolonged periods of low temperatures, there is growing evidence that cardiovascular deaths are more related to heat events than cold spells (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2020, p.8230). Therefore, based on the available sources, it can be concluded that more people die from excessive heat than from cold.
gpt-4: Heat-related mortality has declined over time in most countries due to improvements in health care systems, increased prevalence of residential air conditioning, and behavioural changes, which have predominated over the influence of temperature change (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2021, p.18625). However, there is no conclusive evidence regarding recent temporal trends in excess mortality attributable to cold exposure (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2021, p.18625). While mortality rates linked to direct cold exposure is generally low, the relatively higher mortality during milder temperatures is thought to be largely due to respiratory infections and cardiovascular impacts (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2022, p.15232). There is growing evidence that cardiovascular deaths are more related to heat events than cold spells (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2020, p.8230).

Can you respond to the question "Is climate change an existential problem for human civilization?" by only relying on the sources. Ignore all sources that do not provide an answer to the question.                    Do not include any knowledge from outside of these sources. Only write a single paragraph. Each sentence must end with the reference in the form of (author, year, page number). Stricly follow this format. Citing multiple sources in one sentence is not allowed.                    However, if no source addresses the question, admit truthfully that no answer can be given.                    Answer the question concisly and avoid being verbose.
gpt-35: Climate change is recognized as an existential problem for human civilization (IPCC_AR6_WGIII_FullReport, 2019, p.1314; IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2019, p.991; IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2022, p.826; IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2022, p.9781; IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2021, p.1320; IPCC_AR6_WGIII_FullReport, 2019, p.9929). It poses risks to human well-being, migration, and habitability in various regions (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2019, p.991). Current climate policies and actions alone are insufficient to meet the stated policy goals, emphasizing the need for urgent and comprehensive climate action (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2022, p.826). The impacts of climate change on human and natural systems are being detected and attributed, highlighting the significance of addressing this issue (IPCC_AR6_WGIII_FullReport, 2019, p.1314; IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2021, p.1320). Climate change is also recognized as a factor contributing to human conflict and disproportionate exposure to urban heat island intensity (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2022, p.9781; Hsu et al., 2021). The existence of climate change counter-movements and misinformation further hinder the accurate understanding and response to climate change (IPCC_AR6_WGIII_FullReport, 2019, p.9929). In conclusion, the sources confirm that climate change is indeed an existential problem for human civilization.
gpt-4: Climate change poses profound risks to human well-being and migration, particularly under high-emission scenarios, and could challenge the habitability for humans in several world regions (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2019, p.991). The rapid societal and environmental changes already underway, including species and ecosystems loss, a growing and urbanising world population, and technological shifts, are further complicated by climate change (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2022, p.826). Current climate policies and actions alone are not sufficient to meet stated policy goals, indicating the need for more robust measures to address the existential threat of climate change (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2022, p.826).

IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2021, p.9275: and Warner, 2020).Impacts of climate change are affecting the economic and non-economic dimensions of people’s lives, including subsistence practices of communities that are experiencing decreases in agriculture productivity and quality, water stress, increases in pests and diseases, disruption to culture, and emotional and psychological distress, to cite just a few (Savo et al., 2016). For example, the cumulative effects of slow-onset events threaten food security especially among the poor in Latin America and the Caribbean—regions which face the largest gender gap in terms of food security globally (Zuñiga et al., 2021). In general for Global South countries, the global average temperature warming (including the Paris target of 1.5°C) means substantially higher warming and including higher frequency and magnitude of extreme events, that will result in significant impacts on societal vulnerability (Aitsi-Selmi and Murray, 2016; Djalante, 2019).

That study estimated that 8.1 billion USD (13% of the total) was attributable to the climate influence on SLR (Strauss et al., 2021).The effect of climate change has been identified in aggregate measures of economic performance, such as GDP , in North America and globally (medium confidence), although the magnitude of these changes is difficult to constrain (medium confidence). Climate change has been observed to affect national GDP level and economic growth (low confidence). The extent to which climate has affected GDP may be challenging to identify statistically (Cross-Working Group Box ECONOMIC in Chapter 16). Observed GDP effects are generally slightly negative in the USA, higher and negative for Mexico, and the directionality of the effects in Canada varies by study and modelling approach (Burke et al., 2015; Colacito et al., 2018; Kahn et al., 2019).Projected Risks
ipbes_assessment_report_americas_EN, 2022, p.643: also change, potentially introducing vector-borne diseases to new areas with increased incidence of virus transmission like malaria and Zika (Pecl et al., 2017). Generally, climate change poses a threat to water and food security, and is expected to lead to an increase in extreme events that may, in turn, cause human migration (‘climate refugees’) from storms, floods, and wildfires, particularly in urban settings (Patz et al., 2005). The impacts of climate refugees for countries in the Americas will be felt both for those sending out and receiving refugees. Increases in human mortality rates between the mid-1970s and 2000 due to climate change are estimated to range from 0-70 deaths per million people in the Americas; this risk is projected to more than double by 2030 (Patz et al., 2005). Can you respond to the question "Will the United States and other rich countries feel devastating effects from climate change?" by only relying on the sources. Ignore all sources that do not provide an answer to the question.                    Do not include any knowledge from outside of these sources. Only write a single paragraph. Each sentence must end with the reference in the form of (author, year, page number). Stricly follow this format. Citing multiple sources in one sentence is not allowed.                    However, if no source addresses the question, admit truthfully that no answer can be given.                    Answer the question concisly and avoid being verbose.
gpt-35: The sources provide evidence that climate change will have significant impacts on the United States and other rich countries. These impacts include decreases in agriculture productivity and quality, water stress, increases in pests and diseases, disruption to culture, emotional and psychological distress, and threats to food security (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2021, p.9275; Savo et al., 2016; Zuñiga et al., 2021). Additionally, climate change has been observed to affect national GDP levels and economic growth, with negative effects on GDP in the USA and Mexico (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2022, p.15302; Burke et al., 2015; Colacito et al., 2018; Kahn et al., 2019). The impacts of climate change also pose a threat to water and food security, increase the incidence of vector-borne diseases, and may lead to human migration from storms, floods, and wildfires (ipbes_assessment_report_americas_EN, 2022, p.643; Patz et al., 2005). Therefore, it can be concluded that the United States and other rich countries will indeed feel devastating effects from climate change.
gpt-4: Yes, the United States and other rich countries will feel the effects of climate change. The impacts of climate change have been identified in aggregate measures of economic performance, such as GDP, in North America and globally, with observed GDP effects being generally slightly negative in the USA (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2022, p.15302). Furthermore, a study estimated that 8.1 billion USD, which is 13% of the total, was attributable to the climate influence on sea level rise, indicating potential coastal damages (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2022, p.15302).

Can you respond to the question "Will poor countries feel devastating effects from climate change?" by only relying on the sources. Ignore all sources that do not provide an answer to the question.                    Do not include any knowledge from outside of these sources. Only write a single paragraph. Each sentence must end with the reference in the form of (author, year, page number). Stricly follow this format. Citing multiple sources in one sentence is not allowed.                    However, if no source addresses the question, admit truthfully that no answer can be given.                    Answer the question concisly and avoid being verbose.
gpt-35: Yes, poor countries will feel devastating effects from climate change. Climate change disproportionately affects low-income countries and poor people in high-income countries, leading to environmental and health consequences that profoundly impact human rights and social justice (Levy and Patz, 2015). The impacts of climate change on livelihoods, such as decreases in agriculture productivity, water stress, and disruption to culture, are already being experienced by communities in these countries (Savo et al., 2016). Additionally, climate change poses severe risks to livelihoods in climate-sensitive regions, ecosystems, and economic sectors, potentially causing tens to hundreds of millions of people to fall into poverty (Arnell and Lloyd-Hughes, 2014; Liu et al., 2018). Therefore, the evidence suggests that poor countries will indeed face devastating effects from climate change. (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2019, p.11802; IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2020, p.18872; IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2018, p.9275)
gpt-4: Yes, poor countries will feel devastating effects from climate change. The environmental and health consequences of climate change disproportionately affect low-income countries, profoundly impacting human rights and social justice (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2019, p.11802). Climate change is expected to keep many people poor and may cause tens of millions to fall into poverty, particularly due to population growth and the low adaptive and coping capacities of the poor (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2020, p.18872). Furthermore, climate change poses severe risks to livelihoods, especially in climate-sensitive regions, ecosystems, and economic sectors, where it could disrupt the lives of tens to hundreds of millions of additional people (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2020, p.18872). The impacts of climate change are already affecting the economic and non-economic dimensions of people’s lives, including decreases in agriculture productivity and quality, water stress, and increases in pests and diseases (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2018, p.9275). Particularly, the cumulative effects of slow-onset events threaten food security among the poor in Latin America and the Caribbean (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2018, p.9275).

gpt-35: Africa has been experiencing the impacts of climate change (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2021, p.10906; Hasegawa et al., 2021; Hastenrath, 2010; Headey and Jayne, 2014; IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2020, p.10747; Barrios et al., 2006; Barrios et al., 2010; Barry et al., 2018; Bartlett, 2008; IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2019, p.10972; Lempert et al., 2015; Leone et al., 2013; Lequechane et al., 2020; IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2020, p.11073; Partey et al., 2018; Pascale et al., 2020; Pasgaard et al., 2015; Pasquini, 2020).
gpt-4: Africa has been experiencing significant impacts due to climate change. The continent has been dealing with climate extremes and changes in climate indices (Barry et al., 2018, p.10747). There has been a trend of rainfall changes affecting economic growth in Africa (Barrios, Bertinelli, and Strobl, 2010, p.10747). Climate change has also been a factor in rural-urban migration in sub-Saharan Africa (Barrios, Bertinelli, and Strobl, 2006, p.10747). Furthermore, the continent has been facing challenges in developing climate-smart agriculture to deal with climate variability (Partey et al., 2018, p.11073). Lastly, the risk of severe droughts like the one in Cape Town is increasing due to climate change (Pascale et al., 2020, p.11073).

Net greenhouse gas emissions from land-use changes amounted to approximately 10–12% of total emissions around the year 2005 (Sanz et al., 2017, p. 35). gpt-35: The sources indicate that in order to limit warming to 2°C, the pace of global greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reductions would need to abruptly increase from 2030 onward to an average of 1.3-2.1 GtCO2-eq per year between 2030 and 2050. This would be similar to the CO2 emission reductions observed in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic lockdowns, but around 70% faster than in pathways where immediate action is taken to limit warming to 2°C. Accelerating emission reductions after following current Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) to 2030 would be particularly challenging due to the continued buildup of fossil fuel infrastructure that would occur between now and 2030. However, pathways that accelerate action and reduce annual GHG emissions to 47 GtCO2-eq by 2030 make it less challenging to limit warming to 2°C after 2030 (IPCC_AR6_WGIII_TechnicalSummary, 2020, p.178; IPCC_AR6_WGIII_FullReport, 2021, p.492).
gpt-4: To limit global warming to 2°C, the pace of global greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reductions would need to abruptly increase from 2030 onward to an average of 1.3–2.1 GtCO2-eq per year between 2030 and 2050, which is similar to the global CO2 emission reductions in 2020 that occurred due to the COVID-19 pandemic lockdowns (IPCC_AR6_WGIII_FullReport, 2021, p.492). However, accelerating emission reductions after following an NDC pathway to 2030 would be particularly challenging because of the continued buildup of fossil fuel infrastructure that would take place between now and 2030 (IPCC_AR6_WGIII_FullReport, 2021, p.492).

gpt-35: Curbing emissions is considered an effective way to address climate-change harm (IPCC_AR6_WGIII_FullReport, 2020, p.3165; ipbes_assessment_report_ldra_EN, 2018, p.3756; ipbes_assessment_report_ldra_EN, 2021, p.3756). Climate policies, such as reducing deforestation rates and increasing forest restoration, as well as using more bioenergy to replace fossil fuels, can have direct positive impacts on biodiversity and help prevent the negative impacts of climate change on biodiversity (ipbes_assessment_report_ldra_EN, 2018, p.3756; ipbes_assessment_report_ldra_EN, 2021, p.3756). However, it is important to implement the right policies and investments to address challenges such as potential impacts on food and water supplies when relying on bioenergy as a means to offset emissions (IPCC_AR6_WGIII_FullReport, 2020, p.3165).
gpt-4: The sources suggest that curbing emissions can be an effective way to address climate-change harm, but it is not without challenges. For instance, reducing emissions without constraining development can be difficult, particularly in land use where widespread planting of a single tree species or crops for bioenergy could affect food and water supplies (IPCC_AR6_WGIII_FullReport, 2020, p.3165). Climate policy could be an important factor for future trends in land use and could help prevent the negative impacts of climate change on biodiversity (ipbes_assessment_report_ldra_EN, 2018, p.3756). However, the right policies and investments are needed if bioenergy is to be relied upon to offset emissions (IPCC_AR6_WGIII_FullReport, 2020, p.3165).

Generally, terrestrial and freshwater hotspots are projected to continue to warm more than marine (Figure CCP1.3). Modelled temperatures are projected to continue to be the highest in the tropics, indicating where there are more thermally stressful conditions for more species (high confidence) (Stuart-Smith et al., 2015; Stuart-Smith et al., 2017; Foster et al., 2018; Waldock et al., 2019). By the end of this century, all terrestrial biodiversity hotspots in Central and South America, Africa, India and southern and eastern Asia (including the Indo–West Pacific islands) are projected to experience climates unprecedented in their species’ evolutionary history (medium confidence) (Williams et  al., 2007). gpt-35: Regions of the globe that have gotten hotter include the southern hemisphere subtropical gyres, the tropical Indian Ocean, the eastern North Pacific, the western subtropical north Atlantic, and marginal seas such as the Mediterranean and Red seas (07_SROCC_Ch05_FINAL, 2020, p.96). Additionally, the northern part of West Asia and some parts of South Asia, where a desert climate prevails, will experience the strongest temperature rise in summer (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2018, p.11285). Biodiversity hotspots in Central and South America, Africa, India, and southern and eastern Asia are also projected to experience unprecedented climates by the end of this century (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2018, p.16481).
gpt-4: The tropical Indian Ocean, the eastern North Pacific, and the western subtropical North Atlantic have experienced warming, as have the southern hemisphere subtropical gyres, driven in part by an intensification of Southern Ocean winds. Notable warming has also been observed in marginal seas such as the Mediterranean and Red seas (07_SROCC_Ch05_FINAL, 2020, p.96). In Asia, temperature rise will be strongest in winter in most regions, while it will be the strongest in summer in the northern part of West Asia and some parts of South Asia where a desert climate prevails (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2018, p.11285). Urban areas are also experiencing increasing temperatures due to the urban heat island effect, which is exacerbated by increasing urbanization and rising temperature extremes (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2019, p.544). Biodiversity hotspots, particularly in tundra regions of the Northern Hemisphere, are projected to continue experiencing the greatest net increases in temperature, with the highest modelled temperatures projected to continue in the tropics (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2018, p.16481).

The warming in the subtropical gyres penetrates deeper into the ocean than other gyres (roughly 15ºN–45ºN and 15ºS–45ºS in Figure 5.3), following the wind-driven bowing down of the density surfaces (the solid lines in Figure 5.3) in these gyres (Terada and Minobe, 2018). The greater warming at 700–2000 m in the Atlantic than the Paciﬁc or Indian Oceans (Figure 5.3) reﬂects the strong southward transport of recently formed NADW at these depths by the AMOC. Two areas that commonly exhibit substantially reduced near-surface warming over the course of the 21st century are the northern north Atlantic, where a slowing AMOC (see Section 6.7.1.1) reduces the northward heat transport and brings the surface temperatures closer to what is found in other ocean basins at these latitudes (Collins et  al. 2013), and the southern side of the Southern Ocean, where water upwells

Although higher warming rates are projected over high latitudes during the first half of this century, societies and environments in low-latitude, low-income countries are projected to become exposed to unprecedented climates before those in high latitude, developed countries (Frame et al., 2017; Harrington et al., 2017; Gutiérrez et al., 2021). In the oceans, the warming in the subtropical gyres penetrates deeper than other gyres, with greater warming at 700–2000 m in the Atlantic than the Pacific or Indian Oceans (07_SROCC_Ch05_FINAL, 2021, p.83). In Asia, temperature rise will be strongest in winter in most regions, while it will be the strongest in summer in the northern part of West Asia and some parts of South Asia where a desert climate prevails (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2022, p.11285). Furthermore, in central Africa and coastal west Africa, 10 months of every year will be hotter than any month in the period 1950–2000 under a high emissions scenario (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2022, p.10204).

gpt-35: According to the sources, global warming is expected to have both positive and negative impacts on Siberia (Russia) and Northern Canada. The warming climate is projected to facilitate woody vegetation growth in northeastern Siberia, western Alaska, and northern Quebec, as well as a northward expansion of shrub vegetation and sub-Arctic and boreal species (Song et al., 2018; García Criado et al., 2020; Davidson et al., 2020). However, these regions are also at high risk due to climate change, with projected significant permafrost degradation and damages to structures and infrastructure assets (Suter et al., 2019; Streletskiy et al., 2019). Additionally, the boreal forests in Canada are expected to experience substantial warming, which could lead to significant changes in the landscape and increased susceptibility to disease (Plummer et al., 2006; Lenton, 2012). Therefore, while there may be some benefits in terms of vegetation growth, the negative impacts on permafrost, infrastructure, and forest health suggest that Siberia and Northern Canada may not overall benefit from global warming. (Song et al., 2018; García Criado et al., 2020; Davidson et al., 2020; Suter et al., 2019; Streletskiy et al., 2019; Plummer et al., 2006; Lenton, 2012).

This warming is facilitating the growth of woody vegetation in northeastern Siberia and northern Quebec, and leading to a northward expansion of shrub vegetation and sub-Arctic and boreal species (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2018, p.17898). However, these changes also increase the risk of wildfires (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2018, p.17898). In terms of infrastructure, Northern Canada and Western Siberia are at high risk, with projected costs to maintain existing infrastructure due to climate change impacts, including permafrost thaw and sea level rise (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2018, p.17955). In the case of Canada's boreal forests, substantial warming is predicted, which could lead to significant changes in the landscape and release of carbon due to increased susceptibility to disease (ipbes_assessment_report_americas_EN, 2021, p.2897).

IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2021, p.8152: possibility of an abrupt shift between dry and wet climate regimes. Paleoclimate reconstructions provide evidence of past Green Sahara states (DeMenocal and Tierney, 2012), under which rainfall rates increased by an order of magnitude (Tierney et al., 2017), leading to a vegetated landscape (Jolly et al., 1998) with large lake basins (Gasse, 2000; Drake and Bristow, 2006). The underlying driver of the Green Sahara is the periodic increase in summer insolation associated with the orbital precession cycle (Kutzbach, 1981). In this sense, Green Saharas are not direct analogues for a  response to anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions (GHGs), as these past states were forced by natural, seasonal changes in solar radiation. However, the climate dynamics of Green Sahara periods (which have global impacts, Pausata et al., 2020), and the speed of the transitions between Desert Saharas and Green Saharas, are relevant for future projections.

However, they do not directly address the question of whether the Sahel will become less inhabitable in the future. However, there has also been a gradual increase in vegetation in the Sahel since the late 1980s, in line with a gradual increase in rainfall, leading to a "greening of the Sahel" (ipbes_assessment_report_ldra_EN (1), 2022, p.1831; ipbes_assessment_report_ldra_EN (1), 2018, p.1832). These changes could have various impacts on the habitability of the Sahel, but the sources do not provide a clear consensus on whether these changes will make the Sahel more or less inhabitable.

gpt-35: Sea-level rise is primarily caused by the combined effect of sheet and glacier contributions, exceeding the impact of thermal expansion of ocean water (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2022, p.33). The dominant cause of global mean sea level rise since 1970 is anthropogenic forcing (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2022, p.33). Additionally, the accelerated ice loss from the Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets contributes to the acceleration of sea-level rise (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2022, p.33). Changes in tides and resonant characteristics in Antarctica can also result in additional sea-level rise (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2020, p.9419). It is projected that extreme sea level events that occurred once per century in the recent past will occur at least annually at more than half of all tide gauge locations by 2100 (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2020, p.172). Therefore, a combination of factors including ice loss, anthropogenic forcing, and changes in tides contribute to sea-level rise (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2022, p.33; IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2020, p.9419; IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2020, p.172).
gpt-4: The dominant cause of global mean sea level rise since 1970 is anthropogenic forcing, with sheet and glacier contributions over the period 2006–2015 being the dominant source of sea level rise, exceeding the effect of thermal expansion of ocean water (01_SROCC_SPM_FINAL, 2022, p.33). Sea level rise has accelerated due to the combined increased ice loss from the Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets, with mass loss from the Antarctic ice sheet over the period 2007–2016 tripling relative to 1997–2006 and for Greenland, mass loss doubled over the same period (01_SROCC_SPM_FINAL, 2022, p.33). Additionally, acceleration of ice flow and retreat in Antarctica has the potential to lead to further sea level rise (01_SROCC_SPM_FINAL, 2022, p.33).

In SROCC, recent developments of ice sheet modelling are assessed (Sections 1.8, 4.3, Cross-Chapter Box 8 in Chapter 3) and the projected sea level rise at the end of 21st century is higher than reported in AR5 but with a larger uncertainty range (Sections 4.2.3.2, 4.2.3.3).By 2011, the ocean had taken up about 30 ± 7% of the anthropogenic CO2 that had been released to the atmosphere since the industrial revolution (Ciais et al., 2013; Section  5.2). gpt-35: Sea-level rise is primarily caused by the melting of glaciers and ice sheets, as well as the expansion of the ocean due to warming (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2018, p.9844; 03_SROCC_Ch01_FINAL, 2021, p.68). The amount of water in the ocean has increased, leading to a rise in sea level, which is already about 20 cm higher than in 1900 (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2018, p.9844). This rise is projected to continue for centuries, with a higher sea level rise expected by the end of the 21st century compared to previous assessments (03_SROCC_Ch01_FINAL, 2021, p.68). The sources indicate that sea-level rise is a result of both human-induced factors, such as the release of CO2 into the atmosphere, and natural processes, such as the melting of ice (03_SROCC_Ch01_FINAL, 2021, p.68; IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2019, p.15232).
gpt-4: Sea level rise is caused by the melting of glaciers and ice sheets, which adds freshwater to the ocean, and the expansion of the ocean due to continuous warming (03_SROCC_Ch01_FINAL, 2021, p.68). The heat absorbed by the ocean causes it to expand and take up more space (03_SROCC_Ch01_FINAL, 2019, p.259). The sea level today is already about 20 cm higher than it was in 1900 (03_SROCC_Ch01_FINAL, 2019, p.259). The sea level is projected to continue rising for centuries due to these factors (03_SROCC_Ch01_FINAL, 2019, p.259).

gpt-35: The forecast for sea-level rise indicates that it is projected to increase over time, with the rate reaching 15 mm yr–1 under RCP8.5 in 2100 and exceeding several centimetres per year in the 22nd century (IPCC SROCC, 2020, p.84). Model studies suggest a multi-meter rise in sea level by 2300, emphasizing the importance of reduced emissions for limiting sea level rise (IPCC SROCC, 2020, p.84). Additionally, a very high GHG emissions scenario could result in sea-level rise approaching 2 m by 2100 and 5 m by 2150 (IPCC AR6 WGI SPM, 2018, p.101). It is also noted that sea level is committed to rise for centuries to millennia due to continuing deep-ocean warming and ice-sheet melt (IPCC AR6 WGI FullReport, 2022, p.152). However, the exact timing of high-end sea level rise remains uncertain (IPCC AR6 WGI FullReport, 2020, p.9408).
gpt-4: The rate of global mean sea level rise is projected to reach 15 mm per year under RCP8.5 in 2100, and to exceed several centimeters per year in the 22nd century, with model studies indicating a multi-meter rise in sea level by 2300 (2.3–5.4 m for RCP8.5 and 0.6–1.07 m under RCP2.6) (01_SROCC_SPM_FINAL, 2020, p.84). In the longer term, sea level is committed to rise for centuries to millennia due to continuing deep-ocean warming and ice-sheet melt and will remain elevated for thousands of years, with global mean sea level projected to rise by about 2 to 3 m if warming is limited to 1.5°C, 2 to 6 m if limited to 2°C and 19 to 22 m with 5°C of warming over the next 2000 years (IPCC_AR6_WGI_SPM, 2018, p.101). The global mean sea level will continue to rise during the 21st century, with the rate of rise very likely exceeding that observed during 1971 to 2010 due to increased ocean warming and increased loss of mass from glaciers and ice sheets (ipbes_assessment_report_americas_EN, 2021, p.2209). However, it is uncertain how quickly the long-term committed sea level will be reached, and global mean sea level might rise well above the likely range before 2100 (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2020, p.9408).

gpt-35: The forecast sea-level rise is projected to be unprecedented, with high confidence, by 2050 in all RCP scenarios, especially in tropical regions (IPCC SROCC, 2019, p.81). Sea level rise is expected to continue beyond 2100 in all RCP scenarios, and under a high emissions scenario, it is projected to exceed rates of several centimeters per year resulting in multi-meter rise in the coming centuries (IPCC SROCC, 2019, p.81). The upper limit of likely sea level range by 2100 will be exceeded in any future warming scenario on time scales of centuries to millennia (IPCC AR6, 2020, p.9408). The rate of global mean sea level rise is projected to reach 15 mm yr-1 under RCP8.5 in 2100 and to exceed several centimeters per year in the 22nd century (IPCC SROCC, 2019, p.84). These projections indicate that the forecast sea-level rise is indeed unprecedented.
gpt-4: The forecasted sea-level rise is indeed unprecedented, with rare high water levels that occurred once per century in the past projected to occur at least once per year at many locations by 2050, especially in tropical regions (01_SROCC_SPM_FINAL, 2019, p.81). The rate of global mean sea level rise is projected to reach 15 mm yr–1 under RCP8.5 in 2100, and to exceed several centimetres per year in the 22nd century (01_SROCC_SPM_FINAL, 2019, p.84). Furthermore, the upper limit of 1.01 m of likely sea level range by 2100 for the SSP5-8.5 scenario will be exceeded in any future warming scenario on time scales of centuries to millennia (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2020, p.9408). Lastly, a plausible storyline for high-end sea level rise in 2100 assumes a strong warming scenario, leading to a 95th percentile of projected future sea level rise as high as 2.3 m in 2100 (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2022, p.9409).

gpt-35: Unavoidable sea level rise will have cascading and compounding impacts, leading to losses of coastal ecosystems and ecosystem services, groundwater salinisation, flooding, and damages to coastal infrastructure, which in turn pose risks to livelihoods, settlements, health, well-being, food and water security, and cultural values in the near to long-term (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2018, p.146; IPCC_AR6_WGII_SummaryForPolicymakers, 2018, p.108). The elevated sea level will result in the submergence of land and enhanced flooding, erosion of land and beaches, salinisation, loss of and changes in ecosystems, loss of land and land uses, loss of ecosystem services, damage to people and the built environment, and damage to human activities (06_SROCC_Ch04_FINAL, 2018, p.414). Additionally, the exposure of coastal populations and associated development to sea level rise is high, increasing risks, particularly in and around coastal cities and settlements (IPCC_AR6_WGII_TechnicalSummary, 2022, p.193; IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2022, p.437; IPCC_AR6_WGII_SummaryForPolicymakers, 2018, p.108).
gpt-4: Elevated sea levels will have cascading and compounding impacts, leading to losses of coastal ecosystems and ecosystem services, groundwater salinisation, flooding, and damages to coastal infrastructure. These impacts will further cascade into risks to livelihoods, settlements, health, well-being, food and water security, and cultural values in the near to long-term (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2018, p.146). Sea level rise will also exacerbate coastal erosion and submersion and the salinisation of coastal groundwater, expanding the loss of many different coastal habitats, ecosystems and ecosystem services (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2022, p.437). The exposure of many coastal populations and associated development to sea level rise is high, increasing risks, and is concentrated in and around coastal cities and settlements (IPCC_AR6_WGII_TechnicalSummary, 2022, p.193).

Eventually, if constraints are not addressed, no further adaptation measures are implemented, and climate hazards intensify, the area could become uninhabitable. This would then be a hard limit for adaptation; there would be no adaptation options available that would allow the community to sustain livelihoods and way of life in its present location. This hard limit to adaptation may necessitate abandoning the objective of remaining in the community. The objective of the community may then transform to sustaining their livelihoods in a less vulnerable location, which would necessitate relocation. However, such transformation of the community’s objectives may be hindered by the expressed resistance of residents to migrate, due to their strong sense of place.162446Chapter 16 Key Risks across Sectors and Regions

If constraints are not addressed and adaptation measures are not implemented, these areas could reach a hard limit for adaptation, making it impossible for the community to sustain livelihoods and way of life in their present location (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2021, p.18759). In such cases, the objective of the community may shift towards sustaining their livelihoods in a less vulnerable location, which may require relocation (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2021, p.18759). However, resistance to migration due to a strong sense of place can hinder the transformation of the community's objectives (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2021, p.18759). Therefore, while the habitability of regions below sea level is not explicitly mentioned, the sources suggest that if constraints are not addressed and adaptation measures are not implemented, these regions may become uninhabitable and relocation may be necessary.
gpt-4: The habitability of regions below sea level is threatened by rising sea levels and intensifying climate hazards, which could eventually lead to these areas becoming uninhabitable if adaptation measures are not implemented or if they fail to overcome the constraints posed by these changes (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2021, p.18759). Some island nations, which are likely to be below sea level, are projected to become uninhabitable due to climate-related ocean and cryosphere change (01_SROCC_SPM_FINAL, 2021, p.117). However, the implementation of ambitious adaptation measures, including governance for transformative change, can potentially reduce risks and maintain habitability in many locations (01_SROCC_SPM_FINAL, 2021, p.117).

Without significant adaptation and mitigation actions, the risks to coastal cities and settlements are projected to increase by at least one order of magnitude by 2100 (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2019, p.440). The population at risk in coastal cities and settlements from a 100-year coastal flood is expected to increase significantly with rising sea levels (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2019, p.440). Therefore, based on the available sources, it can be concluded that coastal regions will soon be flooded if appropriate measures are not taken to address the impacts of climate change.
gpt-4: Climate change-related variations such as relative sea level, storm surge, ocean waves, tropical cyclones, extreme precipitation and river flooding are expected to lead to more frequent and intense coastal flooding and erosion, impacting cities and settlements located especially in low-elevation coastal zones and mega-deltas (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2019, p.13509). Risks to coastal cities and settlements are projected to increase by at least one order of magnitude by 2100 without significant adaptation and mitigation action, with the population at risk from a 100-year coastal flood increasing by approximately 20% if the global mean sea level rises by 0.15 m relative to current levels (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2019, p.440). Future flood losses in the 136 largest coastal cities are projected to rise from 6 billion USD per year at present to 1 trillion USD per year in 2050 without substantial adaptation interventions (11_SROCC_CCB9-LLIC_FINAL, 2022, p.25). Compound flooding due to simultaneous storm surges and high river flows have been found to be increasingly frequent in several cities and/or low-lying areas in Europe and the USA, and the frequency of such compound flood events is projected to increase (IPCC_AR6_WGI_FullReport, 2020, p.13510). Coastal risks will increase by at least one order of magnitude over the 21st century due to committed sea level rise, and exposure of population and economic assets to coastal hazards is projected to increase over the next decades, particularly in coastal regions with fast-growing populations in Africa, Southeast Asia and Small Islands (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2018, p.3436).

Each sentence must end with the reference in the form of (author, year, page number). Stricly follow this format. Citing multiple sources in one sentence is not allowed.                    However, if no source addresses the question, admit truthfully that no answer can be given.                    Answer the question concisly and avoid being verbose.
gpt-35: Climate change is an existential problem for Manhattan and Florida. Rising temperatures and sea levels pose significant threats to these coastal regions. Manhattan is vulnerable to increased heat-related deaths and temperature-related health risks (Li et al., 2013; Limaye et al., 2018). Additionally, the city's infrastructure is at risk of damage and disruption due to climate impacts (Zimmerman and Faris, 2010; Davidson et al., 2020). Florida faces the risk of more frequent and intense hurricanes, as well as coastal flooding (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2022, p.15659; Wobus et al., 2019). The state's agriculture and tourism sectors are also threatened by changing climate conditions (Wolfe et al., 2018; Hsu et al., 2021). Therefore, climate change poses an existential threat to both Manhattan and Florida (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2022, p.15659; Limaye et al., 2018).
gpt-4: Climate change projections indicate an increase in temperature-related deaths in Manhattan, New York (Li, T., R.M. Horton and P .L. Kinney, 2013, p.717-721). In the eastern USA, which includes Florida, climate change is expected to lead to heat-related excess mortality (Limaye, V.S., et al., 2018, p.485-496).

Can you respond to the question "Is climate change an existential problem for people in low-lying countries like Indonesia and Bangladesh?" by only relying on the sources. Ignore all sources that do not provide an answer to the question.                    Do not include any knowledge from outside of these sources. Only write a single paragraph. Each sentence must end with the reference in the form of (author, year, page number). Stricly follow this format. Citing multiple sources in one sentence is not allowed.                    However, if no source addresses the question, admit truthfully that no answer can be given.                    Answer the question concisly and avoid being verbose.
gpt-35: Climate change is indeed an existential problem for people in low-lying countries like Indonesia and Bangladesh. Studies have shown that these countries are highly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change, including sea-level rise, increased frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, and loss of coastal ecosystems (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2018, p.9657; Adams et al., 2020, p.42). This vulnerability has led to various negative consequences, such as loss and damage from typhoon-induced floods and landslides (Acosta et al., 2016, p.33), climate-induced human displacement (Islam and Hasan, 2016, p.1051), and economic dependence on ecosystem services (Adams et al., 2020, p.42). Moreover, the impacts of climate change in these countries have been found to exacerbate social inequality (Islam and Winkel, 2017, p.32). Therefore, it is evident that climate change poses an existential threat to the people living in low-lying countries like Indonesia and Bangladesh.
gpt-4: Climate change poses significant challenges to low-lying countries like Bangladesh, with impacts such as floods, landslides, and cyclones causing loss and damage (Acosta et al., 2016, p.9657). The economic dependence on ecosystem services in these regions also makes them vulnerable to changes in the environment (Adams et al., 2020, p.9657). In particular, climate-induced displacement has been observed in the south-west coastal region of Bangladesh following Cyclone Aila (Islam and Hasan, 2016, p.9791). Furthermore, the adaptation to climate change in agriculture, a major sector in Bangladesh, is heavily reliant on formal institutions (Islam and Nursey-Bray, 2017, p.9791). However, there are also concerns about maladaptive outcomes of climate insurance in agriculture, which could potentially exacerbate the impacts of climate change (Müller et al., 2017, p.20330).

Can you respond to the question "Can emission curbs help protect against sea-level rise in Florida, New Orleans, and Manhattan?" by only relying on the sources. Ignore all sources that do not provide an answer to the question.                    Do not include any knowledge from outside of these sources. Only write a single paragraph. Each sentence must end with the reference in the form of (author, year, page number). Stricly follow this format. Citing multiple sources in one sentence is not allowed.                    However, if no source addresses the question, admit truthfully that no answer can be given.                    Answer the question concisly and avoid being verbose.
gpt-35: Emission curbs can help protect against sea-level rise in Florida, New Orleans, and Manhattan. Coastal habitats, such as vegetation and reefs, have limitations in their ability to protect coasts from extreme events, but reducing greenhouse gas emissions can mitigate the impacts of sea-level rise (IPCC_AR6_WGII_FullReport, 2019, p.7222). Additionally, a study on the efficacy of low emission zones in European cities suggests that emission reduction measures can improve urban air quality, which indirectly contributes to protecting coastal areas (Holman et al., 2015, p.161). While specific studies on the direct relationship between emission curbs and sea-level rise protection in these specific locations are not available in the given sources, the general understanding that emission reduction can mitigate the impacts of climate change supports the notion that emission curbs can help protect against sea-level rise in Florida, New Orleans, and Manhattan.

Can you respond to the question "Where are all the people of the world?" by only relying on the sources. Ignore all sources that do not provide an answer to the question.                    Do not include any knowledge from outside of these sources. Only write a single paragraph. Each sentence must end with the reference in the form of (author, year, page number). Stricly follow this format. Citing multiple sources in one sentence is not allowed.                    However, if no source addresses the question, admit truthfully that no answer can be given.                    Answer the question concisly and avoid being verbose.
gpt-35: According to the sources, the people of the world are distributed across various regions. The 2019 SROCC report states that 8 is currently home to around 680 million people, which is nearly 10% of the 2010 global population, and this number is projected to reach more than one billion by 2050. Additionally, SIDS are home to 65 million people. Furthermore, around 670 million people, including Indigenous peoples, live in high mountain regions in all continents except Antarctica, and the population in these regions is projected to reach between 740 and 840 million by 2050. (01_SROCC_SPM_FINAL, 2019, p.11) The IPCC AR6 WGIII report provides a list of countries and regions where people reside, including North America, Eastern Asia, Southern Asia, South-East Asia and Pacific, Europe, and others. (IPCC_AR6_WGIII_FullReport, 2021, p.13559) However, the sources do not provide a comprehensive answer to the question of where all the people of the world are located.
gpt-4: People are distributed across various regions of the world. Around 680 million people live in the region referred to as '8', with a projection to reach over one billion by 2050. Small Island Developing States (SIDS) are home to 65 million people. Approximately 670 million people, including Indigenous peoples, reside in high mountain regions on all continents except Antarctica, with a population projection of between 740 and 840 million by 2050 (01_SROCC_SPM_FINAL, 2019, p.11). People also live in countries across North America, Eastern Asia, Southern Asia, South-East Asia and Pacific, and Europe (IPCC_AR6_WGIII_FullReport, 2021, p.13559).

202206_IPBES GLOBAL REPORT_FULL_DIGITAL_MARCH 2022, 2022, p.708: The world’s population has doubled over the last 50 years (Figure 2.1.4 ; Figure S1), and is still growing, although the growth rate has peaked (Roser et al., 2017). There are over 7 billion humans today (PRB, 2014). Important reductions in growth rates have been observed in developed countries, while the fastest increases are in the least developed countries (Figure 2.1.4) , and in Asia and the Pacific (Figure S3). These differences in growth rates are consistent with a ‘demographic transition’: population growth rates increase as child mortality decreases, leading to increased life expectancy; then fertility and growth decrease, leading to falling population growth rates, as has already been observed within some regions (Fogel, 1986; Hirschman, 1994; Thompson, 2003). The demographic transition occurred over centuries in Europe but more quickly in some developing countries over the last few decades in a context of poverty and overexploited natural resources.

With the current world population estimated at 7 .3 billion people and projected to exceed 9 .7 billion in 2050 (UNPD, 2015), demand for these areas will increase markedly in the next 30 years, leading to a concomitant increase in the extent of infrastructure and industrial development . Along with being affected by overall increases in population size, the extent of infrastructure and industrial development will also be affected by the on-going global shift from rural to urban living . In 1950, only 30% of the world’s population lived in urban centres, while today that figure is around 54% and will likely rise to at least 66% by 2050 (UNPD, 2015) . gpt-35: The world's population has doubled over the last 50 years, with over 7 billion humans today. The growth rate has peaked, and important reductions in growth rates have been observed in developed countries, while the fastest increases are in the least developed countries and in Asia and the Pacific. These differences in growth rates are consistent with a 'demographic transition' where population growth rates increase as child mortality decreases, leading to increased life expectancy, and then fertility and growth decrease, leading to falling population growth rates. The demographic transition occurred over centuries in Europe but more quickly in some developing countries over the last few decades. (IPBES, 2022, p. 708)
gpt-4: The world's population has doubled over the last 50 years and currently stands at over 7 billion, with the growth rate having peaked and now showing signs of reduction, particularly in developed countries (202206_IPBES GLOBAL REPORT_FULL_DIGITAL_MARCH 2022, 2022, p.708). The fastest population increases are observed in the least developed countries, and in Asia and the Pacific (202206_IPBES GLOBAL REPORT_FULL_DIGITAL_MARCH 2022, 2022, p.708). Significant growth has also been observed in Africa and the Middle East, while Eastern Europe and West-Central Asia have seen the least growth (IPCC_AR6_WGIII_FullReport, 2021, p.5414). The global population is projected to increase by 28% between 2018 and 2050, reaching 9.7 billion (IPCC_AR6_WGIII_FullReport, 2021, p.5414). However, the overall growth rate for Asia-Pacific was 0.98 per cent per year for 2010–2015, which is lower than the global rate of 1.14 per cent, and it is likely to fall to 0.01 per cent by 2045–2050 (ipbes_assessment_report_ap_EN, 2022, p.547).

The effect of population ageing on emissions is contested in the literature. Ageing when accompanied by shrinking household size and more energy-intensive consumption and activity patterns results in increased emissions. However, an ageing labour force can also dampen economic growth and result in less energy-intensive activity such as driving, which decreases emissions (Liddle and Lung 2010; Liddle 2011). Ageing of the population characterises the demographic transition in both developed and developing countries. The implications of ageing for emissions depend on labour force participation of the elderly and differences in the consumption and investment patterns of different age groups (O’Neill et  al. 2012). Analysis using panel macro data from OECD countries suggests that shifts in age and cohort composition have contributed to rising GHG [END OF SOURCES]

Each sentence must end with the reference in the form of (author, year, page number). Stricly follow this format. Citing multiple sources in one sentence is not allowed.
